resources.title: spaCy - sentence-transformers
resources.slogan: Pipelines for pretrained sentence-transformers (BERT, RoBERTa, XLM-RoBERTa & Co.) directly within spaCy
resources.description: This library lets you use the embeddings from [sentence-transformers](https://github.com/UKPLab/sentence-transformers) of Docs, Spans and Tokens directly from spaCy. Most models are for the english language but three of them are multilingual.
code_example: # load one of the models listed at https://github.com/MartinoMensio/spacy-sentence-bert/
doc_1 = nlp('Hi there, how are you?')
doc_2 = nlp('Hello there, how are you doing today?')
# use the similarity method that is based on the vectors, on Doc, Span or Token
resources.author: Martino Mensio

resources.title: spacy-streamlit
resources.slogan: spaCy building blocks for Streamlit apps
resources.description: This package contains utilities for visualizing spaCy models and building interactive spaCy-powered apps with [Streamlit](https://streamlit.io). It includes various building blocks you can use in your own Streamlit app, like visualizers for **syntactic dependencies**, **named entities**, **text classification**, **semantic similarity** via word vectors, token attributes, and more.
code_example: default_text = "Sundar Pichai is the CEO of Google."
resources.author: Ines Montani

resources.title: spaczz
resources.slogan: Fuzzy matching and more for spaCy.
resources.description: Spaczz provides fuzzy matching and multi-token regex matching functionality for spaCy. Spaczz's components have similar APIs to their spaCy counterparts and spaczz pipeline components can integrate into spaCy pipelines where they can be saved/loaded as models.
code_example: doc = nlp('Oops, I spelled Bill Gatez wrong.')
print([(ent.text, ent.start, ent.end, ent.label_) for ent in doc.ents])
resources.author: Grant Andersen

resources.title: spaCy - Universal Sentence Encoder
resources.slogan: Make use of Google's Universal Sentence Encoder directly within spaCy
resources.description: This library lets you use Universal Sentence Encoder embeddings of Docs, Spans and Tokens directly from TensorFlow Hub
code_example: doc_1 = nlp('Hi there, how are you?')
doc_2 = nlp('Hello there, how are you doing today?')
# use the similarity method that is based on the vectors, on Doc, Span or Token
resources.author: Martino Mensio

resources.title: whatlies
resources.slogan: Make interactive visualisations to figure out 'what lies' in word embeddings.
resources.description: This small library offers tools to make visualisation easier of both word embeddings as well as operations on them. It has support for spaCy prebuilt models as a first class citizen but also offers support for sense2vec. There's a convenient API to perform linear algebra as well as support for popular transformations like PCA/UMAP/etc.
resources.author: Vincent D. Warmerdam

resources.title: spacy-stanza
resources.slogan: Use the latest Stanza (StanfordNLP) research models directly in spaCy
resources.description:
This package wraps the Stanza (formerly StanfordNLP) library, so you can use Stanford's models as a spaCy pipeline. Using this wrapper, you'll be able to use the following annotations, computed by your pretrained `stanza` model:

- Statistical tokenization (reflected in the `Doc` and its tokens)
 - Lemmatization (`token.lemma` and `token.lemma_`)
 - Part-of-speech tagging (`token.tag`, `token.tag_`, `token.pos`, `token.pos_`)
 - Dependency parsing (`token.dep`, `token.dep_`, `token.head`)
 - Named entity recognition (`doc.ents`, `token.ent_type`, `token.ent_type_`, `token.ent_iob`, `token.ent_iob_`)
 - Sentence segmentation (`doc.sents`)
code_example: doc = nlp("Barack Obama was born in Hawaii. He was elected president in 2008.")
resources.author: Explosion

resources.title: spaCy Server
resources.slogan: 🦜 Containerized HTTP API for spaCy NLP
resources.description: For developers who need programming language agnostic NLP, spaCy Server is a containerized HTTP API that provides industrial-strength natural language processing. Unlike other servers, our server is fast, idiomatic, and well documented.
code_example: curl http://localhost:8080/ner -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d '{"sections": ["My name is John Doe. I grew up in California."]}'
resources.author: Neel Kamath

resources.title: NLP Architect
resources.slogan: Python lib for exploring Deep NLP & NLU by Intel AI

resources.title: NeuroNER
resources.slogan: Named-entity recognition using neural networks

resources.title: NLPre
resources.slogan: Natural Language Preprocessing Library for health data and more
code_example: from nlpre import titlecaps, dedash, identify_parenthetical_phrases
resources.author: Travis Hoppe

resources.title: Chatterbot
resources.slogan: A machine-learning based conversational dialog engine for creating chat bots
code_example: # Create a new chat bot named Charlie
'Sure, I would like to book a flight to Iceland.
response = chatbot.get_response('I would like to book a flight.')
resources.author: Gunther Cox

resources.title: saber
resources.slogan: Deep-learning based tool for information extraction in the biomedical domain
code_example: saber.annotate('The phosphorylation of Hdm2 by MK2 promotes the ubiquitination of p53.')
resources.author: Bader Lab, University of Toronto

resources.title: alibi
resources.slogan: Algorithms for monitoring and explaining machine learning models
resources.author: Seldon

resources.slogan: Emoji handling and meta data as a spaCy pipeline component
resources.description: spaCy v2.0 extension and pipeline component for adding emoji meta data to `Doc` objects. Detects emoji consisting of one or more unicode characters, and can optionally merge multi-char emoji (combined pictures, emoji with skin tone modifiers) into one token. Human-readable emoji descriptions are added as a custom attribute, and an optional lookup table can be provided for your own descriptions. The extension sets the custom `Doc`, `Token` and `Span` attributes `._.is_emoji`, `._.emoji_desc`, `._.has_emoji` and `._.emoji`.
code_example: doc = nlp('This is a test ðŸ˜» ðŸ‘ðŸ¿')
assert doc[5]._.emoji_desc == 'thumbs up dark skin tone'
assert doc._.emoji[1] == ('ðŸ‘ðŸ¿', 5, 'thumbs up dark skin tone')
resources.author: Ines Montani

resources.slogan: Add spellchecking and spelling suggestions to your spaCy pipeline using Hunspell
resources.description: This package uses the [spaCy 2.0 extensions](https://spacy.io/usage/processing-pipelines#extensions) to add [Hunspell](http://hunspell.github.io) support for spellchecking.
resources.author: Motoki Wu

resources.slogan: Language Tool style grammar handling with spaCy
resources.description: This packages leverages the [Matcher API](https://spacy.io/docs/usage/rule-based-matching) in spaCy to quickly match on spaCy tokens not dissimilar to regex. It  reads a `grammar.yml` file to load up custom patterns and returns the results inside `Doc`, `Span`, and `Token`. It is extensible through adding rules to `grammar.yml` (though currently only the simple string matching is implemented).
resources.author: Motoki Wu

resources.slogan: KenLM extension for spaCy 2.0
code_example: spacy_kenlm = spaCyKenLM()  # default model from test.arpa
resources.author: Motoki Wu

resources.slogan: Add text readability meta data to Doc objects
resources.description: spaCy v2.0 pipeline component for calculating readability scores of of text. Provides scores for Flesh-Kincaid grade level, Flesh-Kincaid reading ease, and Dale-Chall.
code_example: doc = nlp("I am some really difficult text to read because I use obnoxiously large words.")
resources.author: Michael Holtzscher

resources.title: Sentence Segmenter
resources.slogan: Custom sentence segmentation for spaCy
resources.author: tc64

resources.title: spaCy-CLD
resources.slogan: Add language detection to your spaCy pipeline using CLD2
resources.description:
spaCy-CLD operates on `Doc` and `Span` spaCy objects. When called on a `Doc` or `Span`, the object is given two attributes: `languages` (a list of up to 3 language codes) and `language_scores` (a dictionary mapping language codes to confidence scores between 0 and 1).

spacy-cld is a little extension that wraps the [PYCLD2](https://github.com/aboSamoor/pycld2) Python library, which in turn wraps the [Compact Language Detector 2](https://github.com/CLD2Owners/cld2) C library originally built at Google for the Chromium project. CLD2 uses character n-grams as features and a Naive Bayes classifier to identify 80+ languages from Unicode text strings (or XML/HTML). It can detect up to 3 different languages in a given document, and reports a confidence score (reported in with each language.
code_example: doc = nlp('This is some English text.')
resources.author: Nicholas D Haynes

resources.slogan: A powerful entity matcher for very large dictionaries, using the FlashText module
resources.description: spaCy v2.0 extension and pipeline component for adding Named Entities metadata to `Doc` objects. Detects Named Entities using dictionaries. The extension sets the custom `Doc`, `Token` and `Span` attributes `._.is_entity`, `._.entity_type`, `._.has_entities` and `._.entities`. Named Entities are matched using the python module `flashtext`, and looked up in the data provided by different dictionaries.
code_example: doc = nlp("I am a product manager for a java and python.")
resources.author: Marc Puig

resources.slogan: German lemmatization with IWNLP
resources.description: This package uses the [spaCy 2.0 extensions](https://spacy.io/usage/processing-pipelines#extensions) to add [IWNLP-py](https://github.com/Liebeck/iwnlp-py) as German lemmatizer directly into your spaCy pipeline.
code_example: doc = nlp('Wir mÃ¶gen FuÃŸballspiele mit ausgedehnten VerlÃ¤ngerungen.')
resources.author: Matthias Liebeck

resources.slogan: German sentiment scores with SentiWS
resources.description: This package uses the [spaCy 2.0 extensions](https://spacy.io/usage/processing-pipelines#extensions) to add [SentiWS](http://wortschatz.uni-leipzig.de/en/download) as German sentiment score directly into your spaCy pipeline.
code_example: doc = nlp('Die Dummheit der Unterwerfung blÃ¼ht in hÃ¼bschen Farben.')
resources.author: Matthias Liebeck

resources.slogan: POS and French lemmatization with Lefff
resources.description: spacy v2.0 extension and pipeline component for adding a French POS and lemmatizer based on [Lefff](https://hal.inria.fr/inria-00521242/).
code_example: doc = nlp(u"Paris est une ville trÃ¨s chÃ¨re.")
print(d.text, d.pos_, d._.melt_tagger, d._.lefff_lemma, d.tag_, d.lemma_)
resources.author: Sami Moustachir

resources.title: Lemmy
resources.slogan: A Danish lemmatizer
resources.description:
Lemmy is a lemmatizer for Danish ðŸ‡©ðŸ‡° . It comes already trained on Dansk SprognÃ¦vns (DSN) word list (â€˜fuldformlisteâ€™) and the Danish Universal Dependencies and is ready for use. Lemmy also supports training on your own dataset. The model currently included in Lemmy was evaluated on the Danish Universal Dependencies dev dataset and scored an accruacy > 99%.

You can use Lemmy as a spaCy extension, more specifcally a spaCy pipeline component. This is highly recommended and makes the lemmas easily accessible from the spaCy tokens. Lemmy makes use of POS tags to predict the lemmas. When wired up to the spaCy pipeline, Lemmy has the benefit of using spaCyâ€™s builtin POS tagger.
code_example: import da_custom_model as da # name of your spaCy model
# create an instance of Lemmy's pipeline component for spaCy
# add the comonent to the spaCy pipeline.
# lemmas can now be accessed using the `._.lemma` attribute on the tokens
resources.author: SÃ¸ren Lind Kristiansen

resources.slogan: Calculates word mover's distance insanely fast
resources.description:
Calculates Word Mover's Distance as described in [From Word Embeddings To Document Distances](http://www.cs.cornell.edu/~kilian/papers/wmd_metric.pdf) by Matt Kusner, Yu Sun, Nicholas Kolkin and Kilian Weinberger.

âš ï¸ **This package is currently only compatible with spaCy v.1x.**
code_example: doc1 = nlp("Politician speaks to the media in Illinois.")
doc2 = nlp("The president greets the press in Chicago.")
resources.author: source{d}

resources.slogan: State-of-the-art coreference resolution based on neural nets and spaCy
resources.description: This coreference resolution module is based on the super fast [spaCy](https://spacy.io/) parser and uses the neural net scoring model described in [Deep Reinforcement Learning for Mention-Ranking Coreference Models](http://cs.stanford.edu/people/kevclark/resources/clark-manning-emnlp2016-deep.pdf) by Kevin Clark and Christopher D. Manning, EMNLP 2016. Since âœ¨Neuralcoref v2.0, you can train the coreference resolution system on your own datasetâ€Šâ€”â€Še.g., another language than English!â€Šâ€”â€Š**provided you have an annotated dataset**. Note that to use neuralcoref with spaCy > 2.1.0, you'll have to install neuralcoref from source.
code_example: doc1 = nlp('My sister has a dog. She loves him.')
doc2 = nlp('Angela lives in Boston. She is quite happy in that city.')
resources.author: Hugging Face

resources.title: Neuralcoref Visualizer
resources.slogan: State-of-the-art coreference resolution based on neural nets and spaCy
resources.description: In short, coreference is the fact that two or more expressions in a text â€“ like pronouns or nouns â€“ link to the same person or thing. It is a classical Natural language processing task, that has seen a revival of interest in the past two years as several research groups applied cutting-edge deep-learning and reinforcement-learning techniques to it. It is also one of the key building blocks to building conversational Artificial intelligences.
resources.author: Hugging Face

resources.slogan: A visualisation tool for spaCy using Hierplane
resources.description: A visualiser for spaCy annotations. This visualisation uses the [Hierplane](https://allenai.github.io/hierplane/) Library to render the dependency parse from spaCy's models. It also includes visualisation of entities and POS tags within nodes.
resources.author: Mark Neumann

resources.title: Rule-based Matcher Explorer
resources.slogan: Test spaCy's rule-based Matcher by creating token patterns interactively
resources.description: Test spaCy's rule-based `Matcher` by creating token patterns interactively and running them over your text. Each token can set multiple attributes like text value, part-of-speech tag or boolean flags. The token-based view lets you explore how spaCy processes your text â€“ and why your pattern matches, or why it doesn't. For more details on rule-based matching, see the [documentation](https://spacy.io/usage/rule-based-matching).
resources.author: Ines Montani

resources.title: displaCy
resources.slogan: A modern syntactic dependency visualizer
resources.description: Visualize spaCy's guess at the syntactic structure of a sentence. Arrows point from children to heads, and are labelled by their relation type.
resources.author: Ines Montani

resources.title: displaCy ENT
resources.slogan: A modern named entity visualizer
resources.description: Visualize spaCy's guess at the named entities in the document. You can filter the displayed types, to only show the annotations you're interested in.
resources.author: Ines Montani

resources.slogan: A small tool that explains spaCy parse results
resources.author: Tyler Neylon

resources.slogan: Beautiful visualizations of how language differs among document types
resources.description: A tool for finding distinguishing terms in small-to-medium-sized corpora, and presenting them in a sexy, interactive scatter plot with non-overlapping term labels. Exploratory data analysis just got more fun.
resources.author: Jason Kessler

resources.title: Rasa
resources.slogan: Turn natural language into structured data
resources.description: Machine learning tools for developers to build, improve, and deploy contextual chatbots and assistants. Powered by open source.
resources.author: Rasa

resources.title: torchtext
resources.slogan: Data loaders and abstractions for text and NLP

resources.title: AllenNLP
resources.slogan: An open-source NLP research library, built on PyTorch and spaCy
resources.description: AllenNLP is a new library designed to accelerate NLP research, by providing a framework that supports modern deep learning workflows for cutting-edge language understanding problems. AllenNLP uses spaCy as a preprocessing component. You can also use Allen NLP to develop spaCy pipeline components, to add annotations to the `Doc` object.
resources.author: Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence

resources.title: scispaCy
resources.slogan: A full spaCy pipeline and models for scientific/biomedical documents
resources.author: Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence

resources.slogan: NLP, before and after spaCy
resources.description: `textacy` is a Python library for performing a variety of natural language processing (NLP) tasks, built on the high-performance `spacy` library. With the fundamentals â€“ tokenization, part-of-speech tagging, dependency parsing, etc. â€“ delegated to another library, `textacy` focuses on the tasks that come before and follow after.
resources.author: Burton DeWilde

resources.slogan: clean and extract metadata from text
resources.description: `textpipe` is a Python package for converting raw text in to clean, readable text and extracting metadata from that text. Its functionalities include transforming raw text into readable text by removing HTML tags and extracting metadata such as the number of words and named entities from the text.
resources.author: Textpipe Contributors

resources.slogan: Full text geoparsing using spaCy, Geonames and Keras
resources.description: Extract the place names from a piece of text, resolve them to the correct place, and return their coordinates and structured geographic information.
code_example: geo.geoparse("I traveled from Oxford to Ottawa.")
resources.author: Andy Halterman

resources.title: Kindred
resources.slogan: Biomedical relation extraction using spaCy
resources.description: Kindred is a package for relation extraction in biomedical texts. Given some training data, it can build a model to identify relations between entities (e.g. drugs, genes, etc) in a sentence.
resources.author: Jake Lever

resources.slogan: Use NLP to go beyond vanilla word2vec
resources.description: sense2vec ([Trask et. al](https://arxiv.org/abs/1511.06388), 2015) is a nice twist on [word2vec](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Word2vec) that lets you learn more interesting, detailed and context-sensitive word vectors. For an interactive example of the technology, see our [sense2vec demo](https://explosion.ai/demos/sense2vec) that lets you explore semantic similarities across all Reddit comments of 2015.
code_example: doc = nlp("A sentence about natural language processing.")
resources.author: Explosion

resources.slogan: An R wrapper for spaCy
code_example: txt <- c(d1 = "spaCy excels at large-scale information extraction tasks.",
d2 = "Mr. Smith goes to North Carolina.")
# process documents and obtain a data.table
resources.author: Kenneth Benoit & Aki Matsuo

resources.title: CleanNLP
resources.slogan: A tidy data model for NLP in R
resources.description: The cleanNLP package is designed to make it as painless as possible to turn raw text into feature-rich data frames. the package offers four backends that can be used for parsing text: `tokenizers`, `udpipe`, `spacy` and `corenlp`.
resources.author: Taylor B. Arnold

resources.slogan: C++ wrapper library for spaCy
resources.description: The goal of spacy-cpp is to expose the functionality of spaCy to C++ applications, and to provide an API that is similar to that of spaCy, enabling rapid development in Python and simple porting to C++.
code_example: auto doc = nlp.parse("This is a sentence.");
resources.author: Kristofer Berggren

resources.slogan: Julia interface for spaCy (work in progress)

resources.slogan: Server/client to load models in a separate, dedicated process
resources.author: Pascal van Kooten

resources.slogan: spaCy REST API, wrapped in a Docker container

resources.slogan: NLP server for spaCy, WordNet and NeuralCoref as a Docker image
code_example: curl http://localhost:8080/nlp/parse?`echo -n "The new twitter is so weird. Seriously. Why is there a new twitter? What was wrong with the old one? Fix it now." | python -c "import urllib, sys; print(urllib.urlencode({'sentence': sys.stdin.read()}))"`
resources.author: Parth Mudgal

resources.slogan: Expose spaCy NLP text parsing to Node.js (and other languages) via Socket.IO
code_example: // start the server with the python client that exposes spacyIO (or use an existing socketIO server at IOPORT)
// Loading spacy may take up to 15s
resources.author: Wah Loon Keng

resources.title: Prodigy
resources.slogan: Radically efficient machine teaching, powered by active learning
resources.description: Prodigy is an annotation tool so efficient that data scientists can do the annotation themselves, enabling a new level of rapid iteration. Whether you're working on entity recognition, intent detection or image classification, Prodigy can help you train and evaluate your models faster. Stream in your own examples or real-world data from live APIs, update your model in real-time and chain models together to build more complex systems.
code_example: prodigy dataset ner_product "Improve PRODUCT on Reddit data"
âœ¨ Starting the web server on port 8080...
resources.author: Explosion

resources.title: Dragonfire
resources.slogan: An open-source virtual assistant for Ubuntu based Linux distributions
resources.author: Dragon Computer

resources.title: Prefect
resources.slogan: Workflow management system designed for modern infrastructure
code_example: with Flow("Natural Language Processing") as flow:
doc = SpacyNLP(text="This is some text", nlp=nlp)
resources.author: Prefect

resources.title: Graphbrain
resources.slogan: Automated meaning extraction and text understanding
resources.description: Graphbrain is an Artificial Intelligence open-source software library and scientific research tool. Its aim is to facilitate automated meaning extraction and text understanding, as well as the exploration and inference of knowledge.
resources.author: Graphbrain

resources.title: Natural Language Processing Using Python
resources.slogan: No Starch Press, 2020
resources.description: Natural Language Processing Using Python is an introduction to natural language processing (NLP), the task of converting human language into data that a computer can process. The book uses spaCy, a leading Python library for NLP, to guide readers through common NLP tasks related to generating and understanding human language with code. It addresses problems like understanding a user's intent, continuing a conversation with a human, and maintaining the state of a conversation.
resources.author: Yuli Vasiliev

resources.title: Introduction to Machine Learning with Python: A Guide for Data Scientists
resources.slogan: O'Reilly, 2016
resources.description: Machine learning has become an integral part of many commercial applications and research projects, but this field is not exclusive to large companies with extensive research teams. If you use Python, even as a beginner, this book will teach you practical ways to build your own machine learning solutions. With all the data available today, machine learning applications are limited only by your imagination.
resources.author: Andreas MÃ¼ller, Sarah Guido

resources.title: Text Analytics with Python
resources.slogan: Apress / Springer, 2016
resources.description: *Text Analytics with Python* teaches you the techniques related to natural language processing and text analytics, and you will gain the skills to know which technique is best suited to solve a particular problem. You will look at each technique and algorithm with both a bird's eye view to understand how it can be used as well as with a microscopic view to understand the mathematical concepts and to implement them to solve your own problems.
resources.author: Dipanjan Sarkar

resources.title: Practical Machine Learning with Python
resources.slogan: Apress, 2017
resources.description: Master the essential skills needed to recognize and solve complex problems with machine learning and deep learning. Using real-world examples that leverage the popular Python machine learning ecosystem, this book is your perfect companion for learning the art and science of machine learning to become a successful practitioner. The concepts, techniques, tools, frameworks, and methodologies used in this book will teach you how to think, design, build, and execute machine learning systems and projects successfully.
resources.author: Dipanjan Sarkar, Raghav Bali, Tushar Sharma

resources.title: Natural Language Processing and Computational Linguistics
resources.slogan: Packt, 2018
resources.description: This book shows you how to use natural language processing, and computational linguistics algorithms, to make inferences and gain insights about data you have. These algorithms are based on statistical machine learning and artificial intelligence techniques. The tools to work with these algorithms are available to you right now - with Python, and tools like Gensim and spaCy.
resources.author: Bhargav Srinivasa-Desikan

resources.title: Learning Path: Mastering spaCy for Natural Language Processing
resources.slogan: O'Reilly, 2017
resources.description: spaCy, a fast, user-friendly library for teaching computers to understand text, simplifies NLP techniques, such as speech tagging and syntactic dependencies, so you can easily extract information, attributes, and objects from massive amounts of text to then document, measure, and analyze. This Learning Path is a hands-on introduction to using spaCy to discover insights through natural language processing. While end-to-end natural language processing solutions can be complex, youâ€™ll learn the linguistics, algorithms, and machine learning skills to get the job done.
resources.author: Aaron Kramer

resources.title: Advanced NLP with spaCy
resources.slogan: A free online course
resources.description: In this free interactive course, you'll learn how to use spaCy to build advanced natural language understanding systems, using both rule-based and machine learning approaches.
resources.author: Ines Montani

resources.title: spaCy's NER model
resources.slogan: Incremental parsing with bloom embeddings and residual CNNs
resources.description: spaCy v2.0's Named Entity Recognition system features a sophisticated word embedding strategy using subword features and "Bloom" embeddings, a deep convolutional neural network with residual connections, and a novel transition-based approach to named entity parsing. The system is designed to give a good balance of efficiency, accuracy and adaptability. In this talk, I sketch out the components of the system, explaining the intuition behind the various choices. I also give a brief introduction to the named entity recognition problem, with an overview of what else Explosion AI is working on, and why.
resources.author: Matthew Honnibal

resources.title: Building new NLP solutions with spaCy and Prodigy
resources.slogan: PyData Berlin 2018
resources.description: In this talk, I will discuss how to address some of the most likely causes of failure for new Natural Language Processing (NLP) projects. My main recommendation is to take an iterative approach: don't assume you know what your pipeline should look like, let alone your annotation schemes or model architectures.
resources.author: Matthew Honnibal

resources.title: Modern NLP in Python
resources.slogan: PyData DC 2016
resources.description: Academic and industry research in Natural Language Processing (NLP) has progressed at an accelerating pace over the last several years. Members of the Python community have been hard at work moving cutting-edge research out of papers and into open source, "batteries included" software libraries that can be applied to practical problems. We'll explore some of these tools for modern NLP in Python.
resources.author: Patrick Harrison

resources.title: Advanced NLP with spaCy Â· A free online course
resources.description: spaCy is a modern Python library for industrial-strength Natural Language Processing. In this free and interactive online course, you'll learn how to use spaCy to build advanced natural language understanding systems, using both rule-based and machine learning approaches.
resources.author: Ines Montani

resources.title: Modernes NLP mit spaCy Â· Ein Gratis-Onlinekurs
resources.description: spaCy ist eine moderne Python-Bibliothek fÃ¼r industriestarkes Natural Language Processing. In diesem kostenlosen und interaktiven Onlinekurs lernst du, mithilfe von spaCy fortgeschrittene Systeme fÃ¼r die Analyse natÃ¼rlicher Sprache zu entwickeln und dabei sowohl regelbasierte Verfahren, als auch moderne Machine-Learning-Technologie einzusetzen.
resources.author: Ines Montani

resources.title: NLP avanzado con spaCy Â· Un curso en lÃ­nea gratis

En este curso en lÃ­nea, interactivo y gratuito, aprenderÃ¡s a usar spaCy para construir sistemas avanzados de comprensiÃ³n de lenguaje natural usando enfoques basados en reglas y en machine learning.

resources.title: Intro to NLP with spaCy (1)
resources.slogan: Episode 1: Data exploration
resources.description: In this new video series, data science instructor Vincent Warmerdam gets started with spaCy, an open-source library for Natural Language Processing in Python. His mission: building a system to automatically detect programming languages in large volumes of text. Follow his process from the first idea to a prototype all the way to data collection and training a statistical named entity recogntion model from scratch.
resources.author: Vincent Warmerdam

resources.title: Intro to NLP with spaCy (2)
resources.slogan: Episode 2: Rule-based Matching
resources.description: In this new video series, data science instructor Vincent Warmerdam gets started with spaCy, an open-source library for Natural Language Processing in Python. His mission: building a system to automatically detect programming languages in large volumes of text. Follow his process from the first idea to a prototype all the way to data collection and training a statistical named entity recogntion model from scratch.
resources.author: Vincent Warmerdam

resources.title: Intro to NLP with spaCy (3)
resources.slogan: Episode 2: Evaluation
resources.description: In this new video series, data science instructor Vincent Warmerdam gets started with spaCy, an open-source library for Natural Language Processing in Python. His mission: building a system to automatically detect programming languages in large volumes of text. Follow his process from the first idea to a prototype all the way to data collection and training a statistical named entity recogntion model from scratch.
resources.author: Vincent Warmerdam

resources.title: Intro to NLP with spaCy (4)
resources.slogan: Episode 4: Named Entity Recognition
resources.description: In this new video series, data science instructor Vincent Warmerdam gets started with spaCy, an open-source library for Natural Language Processing in Python. His mission: building a system to automatically detect programming languages in large volumes of text. Follow his process from the first idea to a prototype all the way to data collection and training a statistical named entity recogntion model from scratch.
resources.author: Vincent Warmerdam

resources.title: Intro to NLP with spaCy (5)
resources.slogan: Episode 5: Rules vs. Machine Learning
resources.description: In this new video series, data science instructor Vincent Warmerdam gets started with spaCy, an open-source library for Natural Language Processing in Python. His mission: building a system to automatically detect programming languages in large volumes of text. Follow his process from the first idea to a prototype all the way to data collection and training a statistical named entity recogntion model from scratch.
resources.author: Vincent Warmerdam

resources.title: Entity Linking functionality in spaCy
resources.slogan: spaCy IRL 2019
resources.author: Sofie Van Landeghem

resources.title: Rethinking rule-based lemmatization
resources.slogan: spaCy IRL 2019
resources.author: Guadalupe Romero

resources.title: ScispaCy: A spaCy pipeline & models for scientific & biomedical text
resources.slogan: spaCy IRL 2019
resources.author: Mark Neumann

resources.title: NLP Highlights #78: Where do corpora come from?
resources.slogan: January 2019
resources.description: Most NLP projects rely crucially on the quality of annotations used for training and evaluating models. In this episode, Matt and Ines of Explosion AI tell us how Prodigy can improve data annotation and model development workflows. Prodigy is an annotation tool implemented as a python library, and it comes with a web application and a command line interface. A developer can define input data streams and design simple annotation interfaces. Prodigy can help break down complex annotation decisions into a series of binary decisions, and it provides easy integration with spaCy models. Developers can specify how models should be modified as new annotations come in in an active learning framework.
resources.author: Matt Gardner, Waleed Ammar (Allen AI)

resources.title: Podcast.__init__ #87: spaCy with Matthew Honnibal
resources.slogan: December 2017
resources.description: As the amount of text available on the internet and in businesses continues to increase, the need for fast and accurate language analysis becomes more prominent. This week Matthew Honnibal, the creator of spaCy, talks about his experiences researching natural language processing and creating a library to make his findings accessible to industry.
resources.author: Tobias Macey

resources.title: Podcast.__init__ #256: An Open Source Toolchain For NLP From Explosion AI
resources.slogan: March 2020
resources.description: The state of the art in natural language processing is a constantly moving target. With the rise of deep learning, previously cutting edge techniques have given way to robust language models. Through it all the team at Explosion AI have built a strong presence with the trifecta of spaCy, Thinc, and Prodigy to support fast and flexible data labeling to feed deep learning models and performant and scalable text processing. In this episode founder and open source author Matthew Honnibal shares his experience growing a business around cutting edge open source libraries for the machine learning developent process.
resources.author: Tobias Macey

resources.title: Talk Python #202: Building a software business
resources.slogan: March 2019
resources.description: One core question around open source is how do you fund it? Well, there is always that PayPal donate button. But that's been a tremendous failure for many projects. Often the go-to answer is consulting. But what if you don't want to trade time for money? You could take things up a notch and change the equation, exchanging value for money. That's what Ines Montani and her co-founder did when they started Explosion AI with spaCy as the foundation.
resources.author: Michael Kennedy

resources.title: TWiML & AI: Practical NLP with spaCy and Prodigy
resources.slogan: May 2019
resources.description: "Ines and I caught up to discuss her various projects, including the aforementioned spaCy, an open-source NLP library built with a focus on industry and production use cases. In our conversation, Ines gives us an overview of the spaCy Library, a look at some of the use cases that excite her, and the Spacy community and contributors. We also discuss her work with Prodigy, an annotation service tool that uses continuous active learning to train models, and finally, what other exciting projects she is working on."
resources.author: Sam Charrington

resources.title: DataHack Radio #23: The Brains behind spaCy
resources.slogan: June 2019
resources.description: "What would you do if you had the chance to pick the brains behind one of the most popular Natural Language Processing (NLP) libraries of our era? A library that has helped usher in the current boom in NLP applications and nurtured tons of NLP scientists? Well â€“ you invite the creators on our popular DataHack Radio podcast and let them do the talking! We are delighted to welcome Ines Montani and Matt Honnibal, the developers of spaCy â€“ a powerful and advanced library for NLP."
resources.author: Analytics Vidhya

resources.title: Practical AI: Modern NLP with spaCy
resources.slogan: December 2019
resources.description: "spaCy is awesome for NLP! Itâ€™s easy to use, has widespread adoption, is open source, and integrates the latest language models. Ines Montani and Matthew Honnibal (core developers of spaCy and co-founders of Explosion) join us to discuss the history of the project, its capabilities, and the latest trends in NLP. We also dig into the practicalities of taking NLP workflows to production. You donâ€™t want to miss this episode!"
resources.author: Daniel Whitenack & Chris Benson

resources.title: Training a custom entity linking mode with spaCy
resources.author: Sofie Van Landeghem

resources.title: ADAM: Question Answering System
resources.slogan: A question answering system that extracts answers from Wikipedia to questions posed in natural language.
code_example: python -m qas.adam 'When was linux kernel version 4.0 released ?'
resources.author: Shirish Kadam

resources.title: EpiTator
resources.slogan: Extracts case counts, resolved location/species/disease names, date ranges and more
resources.description:
EcoHealth Alliance uses EpiTator to catalog the what, where and when of infectious disease case counts reported in online news. Each of these aspects is extracted using independent annotators than can be applied to other domains. EpiTator organizes annotations by creating "AnnoTiers" for each type. AnnoTiers have methods for manipulating, combining and searching annotations. For instance, the `with_following_spans_from()` method can be used to create a new tier that combines a tier of one type (such as numbers), with another (say, kitchenware). The resulting tier will contain all the phrases in the document that match that pattern, like "5 plates" or "2 cups."

Another commonly used method is `group_spans_by_containing_span()` which can be used to do things like find all the spaCy tokens in all the GeoNames a document mentions. spaCy tokens, named entities, sentences and noun chunks are exposed through the spaCy annotator which will create a AnnoTier for each. These are basis of many of the other annotators. EpiTator also includes an annotator for extracting tables embedded in free text articles. Another neat feature is that the lexicons used for entity resolution are all stored in an embedded sqlite database so there is no need to run any external services in order to use EpiTator.
resources.author: EcoHealth Alliance

resources.title: Berkeley Neural Parser
resources.slogan: Constituency Parsing with a Self-Attentive Encoder (ACL 2018)
resources.description: A Python implementation of the parsers described in *"Constituency Parsing with a Self-Attentive Encoder"* from ACL 2018.
code_example: doc = nlp('The time for action is now. It's never too late to do something.')
# (S (NP (NP (DT The) (NN time)) (PP (IN for) (NP (NN action)))) (VP (VBZ is) (ADVP (RB now))) (. .))
resources.author: Nikita Kitaev

resources.title: ExcelCy
resources.slogan: Excel Integration with spaCy. Training NER using XLSX from PDF, DOCX, PPT, PNG or JPG.
resources.description: ExcelCy is a toolkit to integrate Excel to spaCy NLP training experiences. Training NER using XLSX from PDF, DOCX, PPT, PNG or JPG. ExcelCy has pipeline to match Entity with PhraseMatcher or Matcher in regular expression.
code_example: # collect sentences, annotate Entities and train NER using spaCy
# use the nlp object as per spaCy API
doc = excelcy.nlp('Google rebrands its business apps')
# or save it for faster bootstrap for application
resources.author: Robertus Johansyah

resources.title: spacy-graphql
resources.slogan: Query spaCy's linguistic annotations using GraphQL
resources.description: A very simple and experimental app that lets you query spaCy's linguistic annotations using [GraphQL](https://graphql.org/). The API currently supports most token attributes, named entities, sentences and text categories (if available as `doc.cats`, i.e. if you added a text classifier to a model). The `meta` field will return the model meta data. Models are only loaded once and kept in memory.
code_example: nlp(text: "Zuckerberg is the CEO of Facebook.", model: "en_core_web_sm") {
resources.author: Ines Montani

resources.title: spacy-js
resources.slogan: JavaScript API for spaCy with Python REST API
resources.description:
JavaScript interface for accessing linguistic annotations provided by spaCy. This project is mostly experimental and was developed for fun to play around with different ways of mimicking spaCy's Python API.

The results will still be computed in Python and made available via a REST API. The JavaScript API resembles spaCy's Python API as closely as possible (with a few exceptions, as the values are all pre-computed and it's tricky to express complex recursive relationships).
code_example: const doc = await nlp('This is a text about Facebook.');
resources.author: Ines Montani

resources.title: spacy-raspberry
resources.slogan: 64bit Raspberry Pi image for spaCy and neuralcoref
resources.author: Erwan Boehm

resources.title: spacy-wordnet
resources.slogan: WordNet meets spaCy
resources.description: `spacy-wordnet` creates annotations that easily allow the use of WordNet and [WordNet Domains](http://wndomains.fbk.eu/) by using the [NLTK WordNet interface](http://www.nltk.org/howto/wordnet.html)
code_example: # Load an spacy model (supported models are "es" and "en")
# wordnet object link spacy token with nltk wordnet interface by giving acces to
# And automatically tags with wordnet domains
resources.author: recognai

resources.title: spacy_conll
resources.slogan: Parsing to CoNLL with spaCy, spacy-stanza, and spacy-udpipe
resources.description: This module allows you to parse text into CoNLL-U format. You can use it as a command line tool, or embed it in your own scripts by adding it as a custom pipeline component to a spaCy, spacy-stanfordnlp, spacy-stanza, or spacy-udpipe pipeline. It also provides an easy-to-use function to quickly initialize a parser. CoNLL-related properties are added to Doc elements, sentence Spans, and Tokens.
code_example: # Initialise English parser, already including the ConllFormatter as a pipeline component.
# Indicate that we want to get the CoNLL headers in the string output.
# `use_gpu` and `verbose` are specific to stanza (and stanfordnlp). These keywords arguments
# are passed onto their Pipeline() initialisation
doc = nlp("A cookie is a baked or cooked food that is typically small, flat and sweet. It usually contains flour, sugar and some type of oil or fat.")
# Get the CoNLL representation of the whole document, including headers
resources.author: Bram Vanroy

resources.title: spacy-langdetect
resources.slogan: A fully customizable language detection pipeline for spaCy
resources.description: This module allows you to add language detection capabilites to your spaCy pipeline. Also supports custom language detectors!
code_example: # document level language detection. Think of it like average language of the document!
resources.author: Abhijit Balaji

resources.title: Ludwig
resources.slogan: A code-free deep learning toolbox
resources.description: Ludwig makes it easy to build deep learning models for many applications, including NLP ones. It uses spaCy for tokenizing text in different languages.
resources.author: Piero Molino @ Uber AI

resources.title: pic2phrase_bot: Photo Description Generator
resources.slogan: A bot that generates descriptions to submitted photos, in a human-like manner.
resources.description: pic2phrase_bot runs inside Telegram messenger and can be used to generate a phrase describing a submitted photo, employing computer vision, web scraping, and syntactic dependency analysis powered by spaCy.
resources.author: Yuli Vasiliev

resources.title: gracyql
resources.slogan: A thin GraphQL wrapper around spacy
resources.description: An example of a basic [Starlette](https://github.com/encode/starlette) app using [Spacy](https://github.com/explosion/spaCy) and [Graphene](https://github.com/graphql-python/graphene). The main goal is to be able to use the amazing power of spaCy from other languages and retrieving only the information you need thanks to the GraphQL query definition. The GraphQL schema tries to mimic as much as possible the original Spacy API with classes Doc, Span and Token.
resources.author: Olivier Terrier

resources.slogan: A Python module for word inflections
resources.description: This package uses the [spaCy 2.0 extensions](https://spacy.io/usage/processing-pipelines#extensions) to add word inflections to the system.
resources.author: Brad Jascob

resources.slogan: A Python module for English lemmatization and inflection
resources.description: LemmInflect uses a dictionary approach to lemmatize English words and inflect them into forms specified by a user supplied [Universal Dependencies](https://universaldependencies.org/u/pos/) or [Penn Treebank](https://www.ling.upenn.edu/courses/Fall_2003/ling001/penn_treebank_pos.html) tag.  The library works with out-of-vocabulary (OOV) words by applying neural network techniques to classify word forms and choose the appropriate morphing rules. The system acts as a standalone module or as an extension to spaCy.
code_example: doc = nlp('I am testing this example.')
resources.author: Brad Jascob

resources.title: Blackstone
resources.slogan: A spaCy pipeline and model for NLP on unstructured legal text
resources.description: Blackstone is a spaCy model and library for processing long-form, unstructured legal text. Blackstone is an experimental research project from the [Incorporated Council of Law Reporting for England and Wales'](https://iclr.co.uk/) research lab, [ICLR&D](https://research.iclr.co.uk/).
resources.author: ICLR&D

resources.title: NeuralGym
resources.slogan: A little Windows GUI for training models with spaCy
resources.description: NeuralGym is a Python application for Windows with a graphical user interface to train models with spaCy. Run the application, select an output folder, a training data file in spaCy's data format, a spaCy model or blank model and press 'Start'.
resources.author: d5555

resources.title: Holmes
resources.slogan: Information extraction from English and German texts based on predicate logic
resources.description: Holmes is a Python 3 library that supports a number of use cases involving information extraction from English and German texts, including chatbot, structural extraction, topic matching and supervised document classification. There is a [website demonstrating intelligent search based on topic matching](https://holmes-demo.xt.msg.team).
code_example: holmes_manager.register_search_phrase('A big dog chases a cat')
resources.author: Richard Paul Hudson

resources.title: spacy-transformers
resources.slogan: spaCy pipelines for pretrained BERT, XLNet and GPT-2
resources.description: This package provides spaCy model pipelines that wrap [Hugging Face's `transformers`](https://github.com/huggingface/transformers) package, so you can use them in spaCy. The result is convenient access to state-of-the-art transformer architectures, such as BERT, GPT-2, XLNet, etc.
code_example: doc = nlp("Apple shares rose on the news. Apple pie is delicious.")
resources.author: Explosion

resources.title: negspaCy
resources.slogan: spaCy pipeline object for negating concepts in text based on the NegEx algorithm.
resources.description: negspacy is a spaCy pipeline component that evaluates whether Named Entities are negated in text. It adds an extension to 'Span' objects.
code_example: doc = nlp("She does not like Steve Jobs but likes Apple products.")
resources.author: Jeno Pizarro

resources.title: RONEC - Romanian Named Entity Corpus
resources.slogan: Named Entity Recognition corpus for Romanian language.
resources.description: The corpus holds 5127 sentences, annotated with 16 classes, with a total of 26376 annotated entities. The corpus comes into two formats: BRAT and CONLLUP.
code_example: # to train a new model on ronec
python3 -m spacy train ro models output/train_ronec.json output/train_ronec.json -p ent
# load the model and print entities for a simple sentence
doc = nlp("Popescu Ion a fost la Cluj")
resources.author: Stefan Daniel Dumitrescu, Andrei-Marius Avram

resources.title: Numeric Fused-Head
resources.slogan: Numeric Fused-Head Identificaiton and Resolution in English
resources.description: This package provide a wrapper for the Numeric Fused-Head in English. It provides another information layer on numbers that refer to another entity which is not obvious from the syntactic tree.
code_example: doc = nlp("I told you two, that only one of them is the one who will get 2 or 3 icecreams")
resources.author: Yanai Elazar

resources.title: Presidio
resources.slogan: Context aware, pluggable and customizable data protection and PII data anonymization
resources.description: Presidio *(Origin from Latin praesidium â€˜protection, garrisonâ€™)* helps to ensure sensitive text is properly managed and governed. It provides fast ***analytics*** and ***anonymization*** for sensitive text such as credit card numbers, names, locations, social security numbers, bitcoin wallets, US phone numbers and financial data. Presidio analyzes the text using predefined or custom recognizers to identify entities, patterns, formats, and checksums with relevant context.
resources.author: Microsoft

resources.title: Presidio Research
resources.slogan: Toolbox for developing and evaluating PII detectors, NER models for PII and generating fake PII data
resources.description: This package features data-science related tasks for developing new recognizers for Microsoft Presidio. It is used for the evaluation of the entire system, as well as for evaluating specific PII recognizers or PII detection models. Anyone interested in evaluating an existing Microsoft Presidio instance, a specific PII recognizer or to develop new models or logic for detecting PII could leverage the preexisting work in this package. Additionally, anyone interested in generating new data based on previous datasets (e.g. to increase the coverage of entity values) for Named Entity Recognition models could leverage the data generator contained in this package.
resources.author: Microsoft

resources.title: pySBD - python Sentence Boundary Disambiguation
resources.slogan: Rule-based sentence boundary detection that works out-of-the-box
resources.description: pySBD is 'real-world' sentence segmenter which extracts reasonable sentences when the format and domain of the input text are unknown. It is a rules-based algorithm based on [The Golden Rules](https://s3.amazonaws.com/tm-town-nlp-resources/golden_rules.txt) - a set of tests to check accuracy of segmenter in regards to edge case scenarios developed by [TM-Town](https://www.tm-town.com/) dev team. pySBD is python port of ruby gem [Pragmatic Segmenter](https://github.com/diasks2/pragmatic_segmenter).
code_example: doc = nlp('My name is Jonas E. Smith. Please turn to p. 55.')
# [My name is Jonas E. Smith., Please turn to p. 55.]
resources.author: Nipun Sadvilkar

resources.title: cookiecutter-spacy-fastapi
resources.slogan: Docker-based cookiecutter for easy spaCy APIs using FastAPI
resources.description: Docker-based cookiecutter for easy spaCy APIs using FastAPI. The default endpoints expect batch requests with a list of Records in the Azure Search Cognitive Skill format. So out of the box, this cookiecutter can be setup as a Custom Cognitive Skill. For more on Azure Search and Cognitive Skills [see this page](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/search/cognitive-search-custom-skill-interface).
resources.author: Microsoft

resources.title: Dframcy
resources.slogan: Dataframe Integration with spaCy NLP
resources.description: DframCy is a light-weight utility module to integrate Pandas Dataframe to spaCy's linguistic annotation and training tasks.
code_example: doc = dframcy.nlp(u'Apple is looking at buying U.K. startup for $1 billion')
resources.author: Yash Patadia

resources.title: PyTextRank
resources.slogan: Py impl of TextRank for lightweight phrase extraction
resources.description: An implementation of TextRank in Python for use in spaCy pipelines which provides fast, effective phrase extraction from texts, along with extractive summarization. The graph algorithm works independent of a specific natural language and does not require domain knowledge. See (Mihalcea 2004) https://web.eecs.umich.edu/~mihalcea/papers/mihalcea.emnlp04.pdf
code_example: text = 'Compatibility of systems of linear constraints over the set of natural numbers. Criteria of compatibility of a system of linear Diophantine equations, strict inequations, and nonstrict inequations are considered.'
# examine the top-ranked phrases in the document
resources.author: Paco Nathan

resources.title: Spacy Syllables
resources.slogan: Multilingual syllable annotations
resources.description: Spacy Syllables is a pipeline component that adds multilingual syllable annotations to Tokens. It uses Pyphen under the hood and has support for a long list of languages.
resources.author: Johannes ValbjÃ¸rn

resources.title: gobbli
resources.slogan: Deep learning for text classification doesn't have to be scary
resources.description: gobbli is a Python library which wraps several modern deep learning models in a uniform interface that makes it easy to evaluate feasibility and conduct analyses. It leverages the abstractive powers of Docker to hide nearly all dependency management and functional differences between models from the user. It also contains an interactive app for exploring text data and evaluating classification models. spaCy's base text classification models, as well as models integrated from `spacy-transformers`, are available in the collection of classification models. In addition, spaCy is used for data augmentation and document embeddings.
code_example: X_train=['This is a training document.', 'This is another training document.'],
X_valid=['This is a validation sentence.', 'This is another validation sentence.'],
# Set up classifier resources -- Docker image, etc.

resources.title: Spacy FastLang
resources.slogan: Language detection done fast
resources.description: Fast language detection using FastText and Spacy.
code_example: doc = nlp('Life is like a box of chocolates. You never know what you are gonna get.')
resources.author: Thomas Thiebaud

resources.title: MLflow
resources.slogan: An open source platform for the machine learning lifecycle
resources.description: MLflow is an open source platform to manage the ML lifecycle, including experimentation, reproducibility, deployment, and a central model registry. MLflow currently offers four components: Tracking, Projects, Models and Registry.
resources.author: Databricks

resources.title: PyATE
resources.slogan: Python Automated Term Extraction
resources.description: PyATE is a term extraction library written in Python using Spacy POS tagging with Basic, Combo Basic, C-Value, TermExtractor, and Weirdness.
code_example: string = 'Central to the development of cancer are genetic changes that endow these â€œcancer cellsâ€ with many of the hallmarks of cancer, such as self-sufficient growth and resistance to anti-growth and pro-death signals. However, while the genetic changes that occur within cancer cells themselves, such as activated oncogenes or dysfunctional tumor suppressors, are responsible for many aspects of cancer development, they are not sufficient. Tumor promotion and progression are dependent on ancillary processes provided by cells of the tumor environment but that are not necessarily cancerous themselves. Inflammation has long been associated with the development of cancer. This review will discuss the reflexive relationship between cancer and inflammation with particular focus on how considering the role of inflammation in physiologic processes such as the maintenance of tissue homeostasis and repair may provide a logical framework for understanding the connection between the inflammatory response and cancer.'
resources.author: Kevin Lu

resources.title: Contextual Spell Check
resources.slogan: Contextual spell correction using BERT (bidirectional representations)
resources.description: This package currently focuses on Out of Vocabulary (OOV) word or non-word error (NWE) correction using BERT model. The idea of using BERT was to use the context when correcting NWE. In the coming days, I would like to focus on RWE and optimising the package by implementing it in cython.
code_example: doc = nlp('Income was $9.4 milion compared to the prior year of $2.7 milion.')
print(doc._.outcome_spellCheck) #Income was $9.4 million compared to the prior year of $2.7 million.
resources.author: Rajat Goel

resources.title: Texthero
resources.slogan: Text preprocessing, representation and visualization from zero to hero.
resources.description: Texthero is a python package to work with text data efficiently. It empowers NLP developers with a tool to quickly understand any text-based dataset and it provides a solid pipeline to clean and represent text data, from zero to hero.
resources.author: Jonathan Besomi

resources.title: VA COVID-19 NLP BSV
resources.slogan: spaCy pipeline for COVID-19 surveillance.
resources.description: A spaCy rule-based pipeline for identifying positive cases of COVID-19 from clinical text. A version of this system was deployed as part of the US Department of Veterans Affairs biosurveillance response to COVID-19.
code_example: text = 'Pt tested for COVID-19. His wife was recently diagnosed with novel coronavirus. SARS-COV-2: Detected'
resources.author: Alec Chapman

items.title: Training
items.description: Helpers and toolkits for training spaCy models

items.title: Conversational
items.description: Frameworks and utilities for working with conversational text, e.g. for chat bots

items.title: Research
items.description: Frameworks and utilities for developing better NLP models, especially using neural networks

items.title: Scientific
items.description: Frameworks and utilities for scientific text processing

items.title: Visualizers
items.description: Demos and tools to visualize NLP annotations or systems

items.title: Containers & APIs
items.description: Infrastructure tools for managing or deploying spaCy

items.title: Non-Python
items.description: Wrappers, bindings and implementations in other programming languages

items.title: Standalone
items.description: Self-contained libraries or tools that use spaCy under the hood

items.title: Models
items.description: Third-party pretrained models for different languages and domains

items.title: Videos
items.description: Talks and tutorials in video format

items.title: Podcasts
items.description: Episodes about spaCy or interviews with the spaCy team
